summary: We Are A Family-part 3
title: We Are A Family-part 3
body:
Title: We Are A Family.
Pairings: Steve x tony, Peter x Wade, Nat x Clint, Sam x Bucky.
Part: 3/?
Warnings: swearing, fluff, angst, violence, eventual smut, slowburn.
Summary: When Nat comes into the avengers tower with baby Peter Parker, the avengers didn’t know what they were getting themselves into. But now that Peter is here,Steve and Tony both feel protective over him. It doesn’t help that Peter hates everyone other than Steve and tony. But as Steve and tony raise Peter, they start to fall for one another. Will this superfamily work out or will it all turn to hell?

Part 1, Part 2

Tony knew that Steve was spending more time at the supermarket. Knew it was because he wanted to see Peter. And Tony was tempted to do the same thing. But he managed to refrain. Ben had been very clear, he didn’t want them involved. So Tony was making a point of not getting involved. But it was killing a small part of him, not seeing that smiling, giggling face Peter bore. It had been more than a month since Tony had seen that face. Tony shook his head, burying himself deeper into his work. That’s when Steve walked into the workshop, and sat down on the couch.
“Hello to you too Rogers.” Tony murmured dryly.
“Does this not bother you?” Steve demanded and Tony sighed.
“You know it does. But Ben was very clear- we are not supposed to get involved.”
“But-”
“No buts Steve. The best thing we can do is move on and hope the kid comes back to us later on, hope he wants to be an avenger then.” Steve sighed and shook his head.
“I can’t accept that Tony. You can’t either, even if you won’t admit it now. You want to go and get him as much as I do-”
“But we can do nothing Steve. Don’t you have some mission to attend to or?” Steve raised a brow.
“So you’re just going to pretend like the last couple of months never happened?” Steve demanded and Tony sighed.
“What do you want me to say? That I miss a kid that was never mine? That I wish May and Ben would gain some common sense and understand that he’d be better off here? That a part of me hates Ben for taking Peter away? Steve He isn’t ours!” Tony shouted and Steve shook his head.
“But you wanted him to be.”
“That was never an option. He was never going to be ours and he never will be. Now get your self righteous ass out of my workshop!” Tony snapped and Steve shook his head.
“Why won’t you admit that you wanted Peter?” Steve demanded.
“Why do you care?” Tony didn’t want to talk about this.
“Because you’re the only person who understands what it feels like to lose Peter.” Steve murmured and tony sighed.
“Just go Steve. I don’t want to talk about this. I can’t talk about this. Please.” Steve sighed but nodded his head. He got up and left, slamming the door shut behind him.

Steve was standing in the kitchen, bleary eyed and pouring milk into his cereal. He hadn’t spoken to Tony in a week and didn’t feel slightly inclined to talk to him today. When Peter was around… Tony seemed tolerable. Now Tony had reverted back to the same old asshole that he used to be. There was a banging at the front door and with a deep sigh, Steve went to answer it. There was a slight scar from the bullet but he had healed well. Steve opened the door to find May. Her eyes were red and swollen and she had a crying Peter on her hip.
“Take him. Please. I just can’t-”
“What’s wrong?” Steve asked and took Peter.
“I can’t be here.” She then sprinted down the driveway, got in her car and sped off. Peter didn’t settle, only continued to cry.
“Steve?” It was Natasha’s voice. But Steve had his phone out and was calling Ben. Had he gotten into a fight with May? The phone went to voicemail. This time he tried May. She didn’t answer.
“Somethings wrong with May. She was crying and she handed Peter over and then ran…”
“Was Ben there?” Nat asked and Steve shook his head.
“They won’t answer their phones.” Steve made an attempt to calm Peter down but the wailing continued.
“I’m going to take him to Tony. Maybe his powers were too much…” Nat nodded and Steve headed down to Tony’s workshop. When Steve got to the workshop, coffee cups were strewn all about the place.
“Tony?” Steve asked softly and Tony turned. Spotting Peter immediately.
“Why do you have him?” Tony blurted and Steve handed him over. Tony hugging him immediately.
“May was crying, something’s wrong Tony, and I can’t get ahold of her or Ben and-”
“It’s going to be alright Steve. I’ll call them and watch Peter. Maybe you should go out looking for them?” Tony offered.
“No need.” Nat said from the doorway. May beside her.
“May?” Steve asked.
“I feel bad. Leaving him like that, so I turned around and I just, I can’t do it alone.”
“Alone?” Tony asked.
“Ben…” May began crying and shook her head.
“What? What happened May?” Natasha asked gently.
“They caught the guy who killed him. He’s going to prison, but I just…I can’t raise Peter. Not alone.” Ben was dead. Steve shared a look with Tony. This poor woman had lost so much.
“You’re grieving May. Why don’t we look after Peter for a little while and you can decide later. You might just need time…” she nodded.
“I just can’t be here. I can’t do this.” And then she left with Natasha. Tony held Peter tightly to his chest and tony was watching Steve very closely.
“I know we wanted Peter to be ours but…” Tony couldn’t even finish the sentence. But Steve understood.
“Not like this.” Steve agreed.
“If she really doesn’t want him though, I’m not going to abandon him.” Steve nodded.
“Agreed.” Tony sat down and studied Peter, who had mercifully stopped crying.
“We’re going to have to baby proof the entire damn building.” Tony muttered.
“We don’t have to.” Steve thought of the one place he kept secret from the avengers.
“Why not?”
“I have an apartment. In Brooklyn. It’d be easier to look after him there…”
“Why am I only learning about this now?”
“I asked Jarvis to not say anything and…” Steve shrugged.
“Okay, well we can baby proof your secret apartment and take shifts looking after Peter until May makes a decision.” Steve nodded.
“Okay.” This could work. This would work.

Tony soon realised he and Steve had both seriously underestimated just how hard it was to look after Peter. An hour into Steve’s first shift, Tony got a phone call requesting help. Tony had lasted a triumphant three hours before calling Steve. So now they were co-parenting. Full time. Which was strange. But the first time Tony had walked into Steve’s apartment, it felt strange. Homey. Which was a foreign thing to Tony. There was an amazing view of the skyline, there were books and sketches and clothes everywhere. His kitchen was small and could barely fit three people in it. But it was homey. And Tony found he loved to spend time there. More than his workshop. 

“Okay Pete I’m going to make us some lunch, so no climbing the walls or the roof. Okay?” Peter giggled. It had become a routine now, they had been doing this for a couple weeks and the guilt of enjoying this vanished very quickly. Now Tony just enjoyed every second with Peter. But as much as he loved Steve’s apartment, he hated Steve’s couch. It was leather and old and totally uncomfortable to sleep on. He knew he could always go back to the compound to sleep, but hated the idea of leaving Peter. So tony put up with the couch while Steve slept in his bedroom. Tony opened the cupboards and found an old packet of two minute noodles. With a frown, tony decided to check the empty fridge.
“I think we need to go grocery shopping Pete.” Tony muttered. Steve was out, training with Nat or something. It didn’t bother Tony all that much, but it felt a little strange going grocery shopping for cap’s kitchen. What if Tony bought the wrong cereal? And should Tony get coffee? Because Steve didn’t even have a coffee machine here, which Tony was struggling with. It just made more sense to buy the damn coffee machine, but Tony didn’t want to invade Steve’s space.
“This is weird isn’t it kid?” Tony asked but Peter being a toddler, didn’t respond.
“I mean, Steve and I are barely even civil and I’m sleeping on his couch!” Tony ran a hand through his hair. This was crazy. Tony felt tempted to run, but knew that would be stupid. They were going to make this work. For Peter.
“This is gonna work. We will make this work for you kid. So you better appreciate it when you’re older.” Tony told him. Peter merely smiled at tony.
“Are you even hungry?” Tony asked. Peter merely stared and Tony sat down next to him.
“I’ve been researching everything about being a good father. My dad wasn’t good to me and if we do end up keeping you, I want to be a good father. Someone you can count on…” Tony never wanted Peter to walk into someone else’s home and find it strange because he had never experienced a home before.
“Tony?” Steve swung the door open and mercifully had bought food.
“Oh thank god, we were going to starve.” Steve rolled his eyes and placed the food down on the counter.
“I checked this morning before I left, how’s he been today?”
“Good. I think he’s settled into this routine. With you and me and this place.” Steve nodded and began to put things in cupboards and in the fridge.
“I bought you some instant coffee which I know isn’t as good as a coffee machine but-in case this doesn’t work out, I didn’t want to invest in a coffee machine just yet.” It was an olive branch. Steve had bought Tony coffee.
“Thanks.” Steve smiled, seemingly relieved that tony wasn’t going to argue.
“How is everyone back at the compound?” Tony asked.
“Good. They think this is very weird but they’ve gotten used to us not being around as much.” Steve shrugged.
“I was thinking about swinging by later, tinkering with the suit for a bit…” Steve nodded.
“Sure. I’ve got no plans tonight so I’m happy to look after the little guy.” Steve said over his shoulder and tony nodded.
“Have you heard from May recently?” Tony asked.
“No. Not a word. Nat checks up on her though. Makes sure she is doing alright.” Steve murmured and Tony nodded.
“I can’t even begin to imagine what she must be feeling right now.” Tony murmured. And a part of him hoped he would never have to go through that. That he’d never have to experience the horror of losing those he loved the most. He already lost his parents in a car accident.
“She’s a strong woman. She’ll get through this.” Steve began to make lunch and Tony smiled, his stomach seemed to settle a little now that food was on the way.
“Yeah. She will.”

Steve and Tony were in the middle of watching the lion king with Peter when the doorbell rang. It was pouring with rain outside and Steve wasn’t expecting anyone. It had been a risk, buying Tony the coffee. But it seemed worth it now. It was a step in the right direction apparently. Tony paused the movie as Steve got up to answer the door.
“Pizza must be here.” Steve murmured. They had both been far too lazy to cook dinner and had just ordered pizza. Steve grabbed the money and swung the door open, ready to pay for the pizza but it wasn’t the pizza guy standing there.
“May?” His heart was pounding, mind racing.
“Hi Steve. Can I come in?”
“Of course.” And he stepped aside, letting her in.
“Natasha told me you’d be here.” She smiled at Peter and Steve’s heart sunk a little.
“How are you holding up?” Steve asked.
“I’ve been a lot better.” May admitted and Steve noticed how Tony was studying Peter.
“I’m so sorry May.” Steve murmured and she nodded.
“I know I haven’t been fair to the two of you, dropping by to sleep whilst you babysit and abandoning Peter all together. I haven’t been the best guardian to him.” There was a lump in the back of Steve’s throat. His gut was churning. Here it was. Her decision. The truth.
“You’ve been through a lot.” Steve was relieved Tony spoke, because Steve was pretty sure he had lost all of his abillity of speech.
“I know. But I should have been better. Tried harder. And I’m still in a bad way, but I’m seeing a therapist which is helping.” May murmured.
“That’s good.” Twice Peter has been ripped away from them. Steve wasn’t sure he could bare it a third time.
“My therapist helped me come to this decision. I left the two of you as anonymous trusted family friends. But I want you two to know I made this decision with a clear head and I have a second opinion which didn’t in any way effect the outcome of this decision.” Just say it already. Rip it off like a band aid. Steve couldn’t bare the wait. The anticipation. He just wanted to know her choice.
“This wasn’t an easy decision. But it is the best decision. For the both of us.” Tony was watching Steve. They were both terrified and anxious.
“I’ve decided that Peter is better off living with the two of you. But I still want to be involved in his life. Like Friday night dinner or something.” Steve let out a deep and relieved breath. He was ecstatic.
“Of course May.” He couldn’t surprise the grin and neither could tony.
“So we’ll foster him?” Tony asked and May shook her head.
“It would be easier if the two of you simply adopted him. I can arrange for a lawyer to talk to us all on Tuesday.” May explained and tony shared a look with Steve. While the co-parenting was working right now, would it still be working in five months? A year? What about when Peter was a teenager? When they were off on missions? Was adoption truly the best option? A silent conversation passed between them. Steve nodded and Tony did too.
“Sounds perfect May. Thank you.” Steve said, his grin grew even wider.
“We would love to adopt him.” Tony murmured and looked down at Peter. My son. And this time, it was true. Peter really was theirs now. And now they really, truly, did have to make this work. They were in it for the long haul and there was no backing out. Peter was their responsibility and with a bit of luck, it would remain that way forever.

“I can’t accept that Tony. You can’t either, even if you won’t admit it now. You want to go and get him as much as I do-”
“But we can do nothing Steve. Don’t you have some mission to attend to or?” Steve raised a brow.
“So you’re just going to pretend like the last couple of months never happened?” Steve demanded and Tony sighed.
“What do you want me to say? That I miss a kid that was never mine? That I wish May and Ben would gain some common sense and understand that he’d be better off here? That a part of me hates Ben for taking Peter away? Steve He isn’t ours!” Tony shouted and Steve shook his head.
“But you wanted him to be.”
“That was never an option. He was never going to be ours and he never will be. Now get your self righteous ass out of my workshop!” Tony snapped and Steve shook his head.
“Why won’t you admit that you wanted Peter?” Steve demanded.
“Why do you care?” Tony didn’t want to talk about this.
“Because you’re the only person who understands what it feels like to lose Peter.” Steve murmured and tony sighed.
“Just go Steve. I don’t want to talk about this. I can’t talk about this. Please.” Steve sighed but nodded his head. He got up and left, slamming the door shut behind him.

Steve was standing in the kitchen, bleary eyed and pouring milk into his cereal. He hadn’t spoken to Tony in a week and didn’t feel slightly inclined to talk to him today. When Peter was around… Tony seemed tolerable. Now Tony had reverted back to the same old asshole that he used to be. There was a banging at the front door and with a deep sigh, Steve went to answer it. There was a slight scar from the bullet but he had healed well. Steve opened the door to find May. Her eyes were red and swollen and she had a crying Peter on her hip.
“Take him. Please. I just can’t-”
“What’s wrong?” Steve asked and took Peter.
“I can’t be here.” She then sprinted down the driveway, got in her car and sped off. Peter didn’t settle, only continued to cry.
“Steve?” It was Natasha’s voice. But Steve had his phone out and was calling Ben. Had he gotten into a fight with May? The phone went to voicemail. This time he tried May. She didn’t answer.
“Somethings wrong with May. She was crying and she handed Peter over and then ran…”
“Was Ben there?” Nat asked and Steve shook his head.
“They won’t answer their phones.” Steve made an attempt to calm Peter down but the wailing continued.
“I’m going to take him to Tony. Maybe his powers were too much…” Nat nodded and Steve headed down to Tony’s workshop. When Steve got to the workshop, coffee cups were strewn all about the place.
“Tony?” Steve asked softly and Tony turned. Spotting Peter immediately.
“Why do you have him?” Tony blurted and Steve handed him over. Tony hugging him immediately.
“May was crying, something’s wrong Tony, and I can’t get ahold of her or Ben and-”
“It’s going to be alright Steve. I’ll call them and watch Peter. Maybe you should go out looking for them?” Tony offered.
“No need.” Nat said from the doorway. May beside her.
“May?” Steve asked.
“I feel bad. Leaving him like that, so I turned around and I just, I can’t do it alone.”
“Alone?” Tony asked.
“Ben…” May began crying and shook her head.
“What? What happened May?” Natasha asked gently.
“They caught the guy who killed him. He’s going to prison, but I just…I can’t raise Peter. Not alone.” Ben was dead. Steve shared a look with Tony. This poor woman had lost so much.
“You’re grieving May. Why don’t we look after Peter for a little while and you can decide later. You might just need time…” she nodded.
“I just can’t be here. I can’t do this.” And then she left with Natasha. Tony held Peter tightly to his chest and tony was watching Steve very closely.
“I know we wanted Peter to be ours but…” Tony couldn’t even finish the sentence. But Steve understood.
“Not like this.” Steve agreed.
“If she really doesn’t want him though, I’m not going to abandon him.” Steve nodded.
“Agreed.” Tony sat down and studied Peter, who had mercifully stopped crying.
“We’re going to have to baby proof the entire damn building.” Tony muttered.
“We don’t have to.” Steve thought of the one place he kept secret from the avengers.
“Why not?”
“I have an apartment. In Brooklyn. It’d be easier to look after him there…”
“Why am I only learning about this now?”
“I asked Jarvis to not say anything and…” Steve shrugged.
“Okay, well we can baby proof your secret apartment and take shifts looking after Peter until May makes a decision.” Steve nodded.
“Okay.” This could work. This would work.

Tony soon realised he and Steve had both seriously underestimated just how hard it was to look after Peter. An hour into Steve’s first shift, Tony got a phone call requesting help. Tony had lasted a triumphant three hours before calling Steve. So now they were co-parenting. Full time. Which was strange. But the first time Tony had walked into Steve’s apartment, it felt strange. Homey. Which was a foreign thing to Tony. There was an amazing view of the skyline, there were books and sketches and clothes everywhere. His kitchen was small and could barely fit three people in it. But it was homey. And Tony found he loved to spend time there. More than his workshop. 

“Okay Pete I’m going to make us some lunch, so no climbing the walls or the roof. Okay?” Peter giggled. It had become a routine now, they had been doing this for a couple weeks and the guilt of enjoying this vanished very quickly. Now Tony just enjoyed every second with Peter. But as much as he loved Steve’s apartment, he hated Steve’s couch. It was leather and old and totally uncomfortable to sleep on. He knew he could always go back to the compound to sleep, but hated the idea of leaving Peter. So tony put up with the couch while Steve slept in his bedroom. Tony opened the cupboards and found an old packet of two minute noodles. With a frown, tony decided to check the empty fridge.
“I think we need to go grocery shopping Pete.” Tony muttered. Steve was out, training with Nat or something. It didn’t bother Tony all that much, but it felt a little strange going grocery shopping for cap’s kitchen. What if Tony bought the wrong cereal? And should Tony get coffee? Because Steve didn’t even have a coffee machine here, which Tony was struggling with. It just made more sense to buy the damn coffee machine, but Tony didn’t want to invade Steve’s space.
“This is weird isn’t it kid?” Tony asked but Peter being a toddler, didn’t respond.
“I mean, Steve and I are barely even civil and I’m sleeping on his couch!” Tony ran a hand through his hair. This was crazy. Tony felt tempted to run, but knew that would be stupid. They were going to make this work. For Peter.
“This is gonna work. We will make this work for you kid. So you better appreciate it when you’re older.” Tony told him. Peter merely smiled at tony.
“Are you even hungry?” Tony asked. Peter merely stared and Tony sat down next to him.
“I’ve been researching everything about being a good father. My dad wasn’t good to me and if we do end up keeping you, I want to be a good father. Someone you can count on…” Tony never wanted Peter to walk into someone else’s home and find it strange because he had never experienced a home before.
“Tony?” Steve swung the door open and mercifully had bought food.
“Oh thank god, we were going to starve.” Steve rolled his eyes and placed the food down on the counter.
“I checked this morning before I left, how’s he been today?”
“Good. I think he’s settled into this routine. With you and me and this place.” Steve nodded and began to put things in cupboards and in the fridge.
“I bought you some instant coffee which I know isn’t as good as a coffee machine but-in case this doesn’t work out, I didn’t want to invest in a coffee machine just yet.” It was an olive branch. Steve had bought Tony coffee.
“Thanks.” Steve smiled, seemingly relieved that tony wasn’t going to argue.
“How is everyone back at the compound?” Tony asked.
“Good. They think this is very weird but they’ve gotten used to us not being around as much.” Steve shrugged.
“I was thinking about swinging by later, tinkering with the suit for a bit…” Steve nodded.
“Sure. I’ve got no plans tonight so I’m happy to look after the little guy.” Steve said over his shoulder and tony nodded.
“Have you heard from May recently?” Tony asked.
“No. Not a word. Nat checks up on her though. Makes sure she is doing alright.” Steve murmured and Tony nodded.
“I can’t even begin to imagine what she must be feeling right now.” Tony murmured. And a part of him hoped he would never have to go through that. That he’d never have to experience the horror of losing those he loved the most. He already lost his parents in a car accident.
“She’s a strong woman. She’ll get through this.” Steve began to make lunch and Tony smiled, his stomach seemed to settle a little now that food was on the way.
“Yeah. She will.”

Steve and Tony were in the middle of watching the lion king with Peter when the doorbell rang. It was pouring with rain outside and Steve wasn’t expecting anyone. It had been a risk, buying Tony the coffee. But it seemed worth it now. It was a step in the right direction apparently. Tony paused the movie as Steve got up to answer the door.
“Pizza must be here.” Steve murmured. They had both been far too lazy to cook dinner and had just ordered pizza. Steve grabbed the money and swung the door open, ready to pay for the pizza but it wasn’t the pizza guy standing there.
“May?” His heart was pounding, mind racing.
“Hi Steve. Can I come in?”
“Of course.” And he stepped aside, letting her in.
“Natasha told me you’d be here.” She smiled at Peter and Steve’s heart sunk a little.
“How are you holding up?” Steve asked.
“I’ve been a lot better.” May admitted and Steve noticed how Tony was studying Peter.
“I’m so sorry May.” Steve murmured and she nodded.
“I know I haven’t been fair to the two of you, dropping by to sleep whilst you babysit and abandoning Peter all together. I haven’t been the best guardian to him.” There was a lump in the back of Steve’s throat. His gut was churning. Here it was. Her decision. The truth.
“You’ve been through a lot.” Steve was relieved Tony spoke, because Steve was pretty sure he had lost all of his abillity of speech.
“I know. But I should have been better. Tried harder. And I’m still in a bad way, but I’m seeing a therapist which is helping.” May murmured.
“That’s good.” Twice Peter has been ripped away from them. Steve wasn’t sure he could bare it a third time.
“My therapist helped me come to this decision. I left the two of you as anonymous trusted family friends. But I want you two to know I made this decision with a clear head and I have a second opinion which didn’t in any way effect the outcome of this decision.” Just say it already. Rip it off like a band aid. Steve couldn’t bare the wait. The anticipation. He just wanted to know her choice.
“This wasn’t an easy decision. But it is the best decision. For the both of us.” Tony was watching Steve. They were both terrified and anxious.
“I’ve decided that Peter is better off living with the two of you. But I still want to be involved in his life. Like Friday night dinner or something.” Steve let out a deep and relieved breath. He was ecstatic.
“Of course May.” He couldn’t surprise the grin and neither could tony.
“So we’ll foster him?” Tony asked and May shook her head.
“It would be easier if the two of you simply adopted him. I can arrange for a lawyer to talk to us all on Tuesday.” May explained and tony shared a look with Steve. While the co-parenting was working right now, would it still be working in five months? A year? What about when Peter was a teenager? When they were off on missions? Was adoption truly the best option? A silent conversation passed between them. Steve nodded and Tony did too.
“Sounds perfect May. Thank you.” Steve said, his grin grew even wider.
“We would love to adopt him.” Tony murmured and looked down at Peter. My son. And this time, it was true. Peter really was theirs now. And now they really, truly, did have to make this work. They were in it for the long haul and there was no backing out. Peter was their responsibility and with a bit of luck, it would remain that way forever.

blog.name: npgk
blog.title: Within the sound of Silence
blog.description:
Fangirl a tempo pieno e slasher in incognito. 
Assisto un high-functioning sociopath e viaggio spesso tra Camelot, Westeros, Narnia e Middle-Earth. Quando mi capita finisco nell'antica Roma con gladiatori cazzuti, nell'antica Grecia con un Pitagora più simpatico del solito, nella Scandinavia dei primi secoli e nella Scozia del XVIII secolo in compagnia degli highlanders.
Spesso mi diletto nel canto insieme al Glee club e a quei poveri sfigati degli Amis de l'ABC. E amo la matematica e vorrei Sheldon come insegnante.
Nel tempo libero salvo il l'Enchanted Forest dall'Hydra in compagnia degli Avengers.
Tributo, strega e impavida, sono sposata segretamente con Tom Hiddleston e Benedict Cumberbatch (tra i tanti).
La musica celtica e tutto ciò che è medievale mi fa credere sempre di più di essere nata nel secolo sbagliato.
Il mio sogno è quello di diventare una mutante e di andare nello spazio a bordo dell'Enterprise per sconfiggere Darth Vader.

summary:
Ok so have any of you Marvel fans (especially black widow fans can I get a yeah boi) read this book??
I'm just over half way...
body:
Forever Red *Black Widow Book*

Ok so have any of you Marvel fans (especially black widow fans can I get a yeah boi) read this book??

I’m just over half way through and it’s pretty darn good!

*SPOILER ALERT FROM HERE*

Ok so its about black widow (obviously) and another girl (Ava) who wasn’t part of the Red Room the same as Natasha, but was experimented on by the same man who ran the Red Room (Ivan Somodorov).

But it gives us a few clues about certain stuffs in the marvel universe:

  • The book starts with an “8 years previously” and it mentions that at that point, Natasha is quite new to shield. So say she’s been their 2-4 years (I only say that long because she was on a solo mission which means she must have been trusted at that point, and that trust ain’t easy to get). The majority of the book then takes place about a year after New York. Which means Natasha has actually only been a good guy for around 10-14 years. Which might seem a lot for a normal person, but in the comic books she is similar to Steve Rogers and the Winter Soldier, she’s genetically advanced and in the comics had been around since pre WW2. Plus there is a brief mention that her birthday is redacted from her file which could show that she’s actually a lot older than she looks and it’s never implicitly contradicted that in the movies (or book, so far).

Bear in mind that the only person to state that this is part of the MCU is the author if the book, no one else from Marvel has confirmed or denied that…

  • Now this is a big *spoiler* but Coulson is in it. Not just in the first chapter either he is in it throughout. Him and Nat talk and he helps her out for a bit. Now do you remember me mentioning that this is after New York? This is indesputible because there is 1 or 2 pages dedicated to Natasha thinking about how hard it’s been to keep a low profile since the Avengers became world famous, how she’s had to work a whole lot harder to disguise herself because the entire world now knows what she looks like.
  • Natasha knowing Coulson is alive isn’t even the best part.
  • Tony Stark is in it.
  • He only appears for a few chapters (so far, he might come back) to try and help Natasha and Ava with a lil problem they have.
  • But
  • He
  • Mentions
  • Natasha getting help from Coulson.
  • Obviously the rest of his line won’t make sense until you read the book but he says this “So you circle the wagons, pick up Mini-Me, take out Ivan’s welcome party, hop aboard Coulson’s good ship Lollipop and hitch a ride to S.H.I.E.L.D.’s doorstep?”. Plus earlier it says “a few well placed calls from Coulson” help Tony and Natasha get access to what they want access to at the New York Triskellion. So this HEAVILY implies that Tony Stark also knew Coulson was alive?? Which leads on to the question do the others know? Did they tell them or did they realise he was *dead* for a reason and keep the secret?

….Or it could be set in an entirely alternate universe where Coulson never died….in which case half this post is pointless (but it’s still a good book so go read)

  • Plus there are a few other bits, for example Tony makes a Star Trek reference proving many people’s headcannons that he is a huge nerd. And Natasha follows that with “is that before or after they blow up the death star” proving that even in the midst and a crisis she is a HUGE troll….OR…. she is completely anti-nerd and doesn’t care for movies or pop culture…

Now I’m not gonna lie, it’s not the BEST book I’ve ever read (maybe because I’m a year or 2 too old) but it’s well written and thorough and it gives a really big insight to Natasha’ s character. When she isn’t with her Avenger buddies, people she trusts implicitly, she is cold and calculating and has no fucking clue on how to deal with teenagers, or how to connect with Ava (who is very similar to her in experiences and past traumas). Through this it also gives a large insight into what the Red Room was like, which lots of fans have been searching for for a long time. Also there are lots of bits in Russian which is interesting and it’s written in a way that you can usually understand what it translates to (or it’s translated for you).

However, the only major downside to this book that I can find is that Clint Barton isn’t in it. So far he hasn’t even been mentioned (I think😅) and I looked some things up and it doesn’t look like he comes into the second half of the book either. Now as much as that is disappointed there are still 1 or 2 books (i forget) in this series in which he might appear in. I doubt it though.

All in all its a thouraghly enjoyable book and I definitely wouldn’t mind any Black Widow movie to be based on it (although the inclusion on Clint Barton would be preferable) so you BW fans out there go read it it’s good👍👍

-E

summary: If Thanos was true in his word about half of the universe dying as random. There is a good chance that in the vastness of the...
body:
If Thanos was true in his word about half of the universe dying as random. There is a good chance that in the vastness of the universe one-many civilizations may have lost enough of people in their reproductive cycle to cause irreparable damage and lead to their doom well before their resources might have run dry.


(Assuming that at least one in however many civilizations are similar in how they reproduce of course)

summary: Okay so I have been given permission to enter the competition for the Tom Holland set thing run by The Brothers Trust. However,...
body:
Okay so I have been given permission to enter the competition for the Tom Holland set thing run by The Brothers Trust. However, mum wants me to do a full check on where my money is going. It is going to the Edward Charles Foundation. I can’t find much information and while I really want to enter, I’m apprehensive.

So, if you know anything about it, or can find a reason I shouldn’t donate, please let me know either through this post or PM me.

Thanks ☺️
